Remuneration transparency refers to the degree to which information about compensation, including salaries, bonuses, benefits, and other forms of remuneration, is openly and readily available to relevant stakeholders within an organization and, in some cases, to the public. Remuneration transparency often involves disclosing the compensation packages of top executives, including CEOs, CFOs, and other senior management positions.

Remuneration philosophy refers to the principles and beliefs guiding employee compensation. It encompasses the fundamental values, objectives, and priorities that shape decisions regarding how salaries, benefits, incentives, and other forms of compensation are structured and administered within the organization.

An annual remuneration review is a structured process by organizations to evaluate and adjust employee compensation annually. This review typically involves assessing individual and group performance, market trends, budgetary considerations, and organizational priorities to determine appropriate salary changes, bonuses, incentives, benefits, and other forms of compensation.

The directors' remuneration is paid in the form of directors' fees. Additional fees are paid to the chair of the Board concerning work carried out by individual directors on various Board committees to reflect the additional responsibilities of these positions.

A long-term incentive (LTI) is a form of compensation provided to employees, typically executives and senior management, as part of their overall remuneration package.
